name: Nuisance or Annoyance to Neighbors
short_description: Tenant or visitor causing nuisance/annoyance or convicted of using dwelling for immoral/illegal purposes

nuisance_or_annoyance.conduct: Causing or likely to cause nuisance or annoyance

conviction_based.alternative: Convicted of using dwelling or allowing use for immoral or illegal purpose

arrest_for_breach.alternative: Arrested for breach of injunction under Housing Act 1996 s152 or 153

notice_period.section_8_notice: 2 weeks if based on serious antisocial behavior
notice_period.court_proceedings: Can be started after notice period

evidence_required: Noise recordings or logs with dates/times
Police reports or crime reference numbers
Council noise or environmental health reports

strong_cases: Regular loud parties with police attendance
Threatening or violent behavior to neighbors

high_probability: Criminal conviction for illegal use of property
medium_probability: Pattern of nuisance but not severe
Recent improvement but past pattern strong

red_flags: Tenant has evidence of good behavior
Complainant has history of complaints about multiple tenants
Normal living noise described as nuisance

costs.witness_expenses: May need to cover neighbor attendance

tenant_defenses: Tenant has taken steps to address issues
notes: Ground 14 is DISCRETIONARY but powerful for antisocial behavior. Courts take ASB seriously but require strong evidence. Multiple independent witnesses crucial. Criminal conviction makes case very strong. Often used with injunctions.
case_law: Northampton BC v Lovatt [1998] - Pattern of behavior needed
Manchester CC v Lawler [1999] - Evidence must be credible
Sheffield CC v Shaw [2007] - Serious ASB justifies swift action
Moat Housing v Rejmie [2012] - Single incident can suffice if serious
court_considerations: What is the nature and severity of conduct?
How many incidents over what period?
Could injunction with suspended order work?

immoral_or_illegal_use.evidence: Criminal conviction is strong proof but not essential
immoral_or_illegal_use.note: Can be proven by balance of probabilities without conviction

injunctions.power: Can seek injunction alongside or before possession
injunctions.benefit: Prevents specific conduct, breach can support possession
